content: Iâll just echo what Bob said - as we think about the co-brand program, weâve talked about this with the street a little bit, we made the strategic decision back when we launched the current version of the program to invest all the economics back into the members with the goal of driving lifetime value, and weâve been really pleased with how thatâs performed over the last several years. The team across the board at CapOne is incredible in everything that they do, and as we think how that plays through to the growth in the next program, we think that there is a substantial leg higher from here in terms of the growth with the membership base, so there will be a little bit--in term of the KPIs, there will be a little bit of a slowdown here--not a slowdown but a pause as we shut off acquisition in the coming days on the current program as we work through the transition, so youâll likely see a pause in the higher tier membership penetration as we report Q4, and then as we get the program launched in the first half of next year, youâll see it then reaccelerate from there as we start acquisition with the new program. Weâve also had headwinds all over the business, most notably in margins this year as supply chain costs and general merchandise markdowns really impacted our margins throughout the year, and so I do think it will be tough to lap the gas income that weâve seen this year. We feel like weâre going in the right direction, and all the clubs weâve opened in the last few years have outperformed what we thought they would do, so that gives us a ton of confidence to continue to keep our foot on the gas from a real estate perspective. The quality of the conversations and the execution that weâre seeing from the team, as well as the new planning and allocation folks that weâve brought in, has really just changed the game for us, so Iâm very bullish on our GM prospects over the long term with our team and looking forward to getting into next year, so we can see how the members react to what weâre doing. But this year has been an interesting one, to the core of your question, where weâve made so much money on gasoline, weâve used that to spend into the beat, if you will, so we have made our gas prices a little bit even lower than normal to showcase even more value, and then weâve taken that gas profit and invested it in other places in the business, so think about helping our members through these inflationary times. I donât know that that slows down in 4Q, but as our competitors have noted and I talked about earlier, our GM performance was a little bit soft in the third quarter and youâve got a tough market out there, and GM becomes a bigger piece of our business in the fourth quarter, so youâre absolutely correct - the guidance that weâve got out there, comps in the 4% to 5% range for 4Q, would imply a decent decel. Over the past few years, weâve already seen the effect of a fee increase, right - the average dollars per member is well over $60 at this point, itâs up about $5 in the last few years, so weâve mixed our business up to really look like it has had a fee increase when we havenât changed the sticker price to our members, so itâs sort of an unappreciated thing that weâve been able to do over the past few years, and our membership team has done a fantastic job doing that. IT also comes to one of the core reasons weâre doing the co-brand transition, right - that has been the fastest growing part of our premium tier memberships over the years, and with the new value prop that weâll announce in January, we only expect that to get better. As you remember, the longer term story four years ago or so, we didnât really have a digital business to speak of, and weâve spent a bunch of time building the infrastructure, and lo and behold now weâre well over a billion dollars and 9%-ish of our business.
